instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used to predict the TVB-N content in Pacific white shrimp?
Output: The related study used nir spectrum to predict the TVB-N content in Pacific white shrimp.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to predict the TVB-N content in Pacific white shrimp?
Output: Feature wavelength selection and feature variable extraction methods were used to predict the TVB-N content in Pacific white shrimp.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the prediction models to predict the TVB-N content in Pacific white shrimp, and how well did this metric perform?
Output: The metric chosen to predict the TVB-N content in Pacific white shrimp was the R-p(2) value. The R-p(2) value is a measure of the goodness of fit of the model and indicates the proportion of the variance in the TVB-N content that can be explained by the model. In the related study, the best prediction model, SAEs-LS-SVM, had an R-p(2) value of 0.921. This indicates that the model was able to explain approximately 92.1% of the variance in the TVB-N content. Therefore, the chosen metric performed well in predicting TVB-N content.

instruction: What machine learning models were used to build the prediction models for TVB-N content in Pacific white shrimp using hyperspectral imaging?
Output: The machine learning models used to build the prediction models for TVB-N content in Pacific white shrimp using hyperspectral imaging were least-squares support vector machine (LS-SVM), partial least squares regression (PLSR), and multiple linear regression (MLR).

instruction: How did the SAEs-based prediction models compare to the full wavelengths-based or SPA-based prediction models in predicting TVB-N content in Pacific white shrimp using hyperspectral imaging?
Output: The SAEs-based prediction models (SAEs-LS-SVM, SAEs-MLR, and SAEs-PLSR) performed better than the full wavelengths-based or SPA-based prediction models in predicting TVB-N content in Pacific white shrimp using hyperspectral imaging.
